justification: Under “Dictionary Coding” the authors state that one of the 15 dictionary dimensions used to code responses is Sociability.
The article lists Morality among the 15 dictionary dimensions that served as word‐list measures for coding impressions.
Ability is explicitly named as one of the dictionary dimensions (“The 15 dictionary dimensions are: … Ability …”).
Assertiveness appears in the enumerated list of dictionaries employed to measure face-impression content.
The Emotions dimension is included in the set of 15 word-list dictionaries the authors used for coding open-ended responses.
Social Groups is listed as one of the dictionaries applied to classify participants’ spontaneous descriptors.
Status is mentioned in the catalogue of 15 dictionary dimensions that operationalise impression content.
Beliefs is identified among the dictionary dimensions; the authors note direction scoring for responses matched to the Beliefs dictionary.
Uniqueness is specifically cited in the list of dictionaries used to code spontaneous face impressions.
Family appears in the enumeration of 15 dictionary dimensions serving as measurement tools.
Health is included in the set of dictionary dimensions that code open-ended impression words.
Occupation is named as one of the 15 word-list dictionaries employed for measurement.
Geography is listed among the dictionary dimensions used to classify participants’ descriptors.
Appearance is one of the dictionary dimensions; the authors highlight it as the most prevalent content category.
The text notes that a Beauty dictionary, ‘a subset of the Appearance dictionary,’ was used separately because of its relevance.
